commit_message:
Add granular policy rules for resource providers inventories

This adds granular policy rules for the various
/resource_providers/{uuid}/inventories* APIs. The default
rule (requires role:admin) is backward compatible with
existing deployments.

Part of blueprint granular-placement-policy

Change-Id: I382f958a04415250e06fa29a2bfcb9806c028248

Drop mox3 from TemplateVersionsTests

Also fix traceback while running tests against newer versions
of horizon.

commit_message:
Add granular policy rules for /resource_classes*

This adds policy rules or the various /resource_classes*
routes with the default being backward compatible with
existing deployments (requires role:admin).

The "non admin forbidden non json" gabbit had to be changed
because the policy check moved so the test would fail with a
406 response instead of 403.

Part of blueprint granular-placement-policy

Change-Id: I90ef62e8e7b9e75830ac60e0c5c7e92845ab4afe

commit_message:
Introduce API definition of Floating IP Port Forwarding

This patch introduces the port forwarding API definition which extends
the current Floating IP API.

This patch partially implements the following spec:
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/rocky/port-forwarding.html

Change-Id: I86adb014c5c9b55b00085849c3ebdd38adfed85b
Co-Authored-By: zhaobo <zhaobo6@huawei.com>
Partial-Bug: #1491317

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-09-08 14:36:23.000000000', 'message': 'Enable Python hash seed randomization in tests

Unit tests should run with hash seed randomization
on, to ensure code is not introduced that relies on
ordered access of dicts, sets, etc.

Python 3.3 enables this at runtime by default.

Change-Id: I67804f6238c09b40b1828e4d15e703756ccfef31
'}]
commit_message:
Enable Python hash seed randomization in tests

Unit tests should run with hash seed randomization
on, to ensure code is not introduced that relies on
ordered access of dicts, sets, etc.

Python 3.3 enables this at runtime by default.

Change-Id: I67804f6238c09b40b1828e4d15e703756ccfef31

commit_message:
Use Octavia for LoadBalancer type service

In the OpenStack deployment with Octavia service enabled, the octavia
service should be used not only for master nodes high availability, but
also for k8s LoadBalancer type service implementation as well.

Change-Id: Ib61f59507510253794a4780a91e49aa6682c8039
Closes-Bug: #1770133

commit_message:
Rename spec to match blueprint

This is an old spec but it provides useful context and was difficult to
find due to the naming. Resolve this.

Part of blueprint sriov-pf-passthrough-neutron-port

Change-Id: I864daa6eafd7eadb00076f51240a1726122463d6
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2018-05-21 18:23:02.000000000', 'message': 'NetApp ONTAP iSCSI: Force exception on online extend

The Netapp ONTAP iSCSI driver does not support online volume extend. It
may work if the requested size does not exceed the LUN max geometry,
otherwise it will require the LUN to be detached. In such case, the
backend currently detaches and leaves the volume in an inconsistent
state.

This patch forces the ONTAP iSCSI driver to raise an exception whenever
an online extend is requested and it detects it would exceed the LUN max
geometry.

Change-Id: Ie3dddbc05c6cd32e27168d68f4cb819364b0438c
Closes-Bug: #1712651
(cherry picked from commit 2b60912d5667350eae7ecbc67d4dba3658518d10)
'}]
commit_message:
NetApp ONTAP iSCSI: Force exception on online extend

The Netapp ONTAP iSCSI driver does not support online volume extend. It
may work if the requested size does not exceed the LUN max geometry,
otherwise it will require the LUN to be detached. In such case, the
backend currently detaches and leaves the volume in an inconsistent
state.

This patch forces the ONTAP iSCSI driver to raise an exception whenever
an online extend is requested and it detects it would exceed the LUN max
geometry.

Change-Id: Ie3dddbc05c6cd32e27168d68f4cb819364b0438c
Closes-Bug: #1712651
(cherry picked from commit 2b60912d5667350eae7ecbc67d4dba3658518d10)

commit_message:
Pin cmd2 to the last python2 version of the library

The cmd2-0.9.0 is python3-only and the tempest venv is built
unconstrained, so it's trying to bring in the latest version
which is incompatible with python2. We pin the library to
ensure that the venv build completes correctly.

Depends-On: I35e3688ae632d5f7747f32dafc41d23883c033c5
Change-Id: Id5b9274ce39dec3d5ee295d7ef941bf42ca7cbd2
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 8c7b78424f699f19ea0a11e4c9dfee78cee1976f)

commit_message:
Create distutils cfg before install and build

Some old Python2 pip sources still use setup.py, so when you provide
your own index sources via repo_build_pip_default_index the 'Download
requirement pip sources' task might fail while trying to reach a
default external PyPI index URL.

Change-Id: Ib7d2a9aee9b13f38b73136f22f0b51e766c8dd10
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 5ceedbbb5fc8dddf0437c846a5395484b6de81a8)

commit_message:
Vagrantfile: Add workaround for Virtualbox bug on guest audio config

Seems like Virtualbox is having troubles adding audio to guests[1].
Since we don't care about audio, we can simply disable that in order
to workaround this problem:

/usr/share/vagrant/plugins/providers/virtualbox/driver/version_5_0.rb:670:in
`start': There was an error while executing `VBoxManage`, a CLI used by
Vagrant (Vagrant::Errors ::VBoxManageError)
for controlling VirtualBox. The command and stderr is shown below.

Command: ["startvm", "145b5aec-b9c5-4feb-9728-e8670bb71b48", "--type",
"headless"]

Stderr: VBoxManage: error: The specified string / bytes buffer was to
small. Specify a larger one and retry. (VERR_CFGM_NOT_ENOUGH_SPACE)
VBoxManage: error: Details: code NS_ERROR_FAILURE (0x80004005),
component ConsoleWrap, interface IConsole
There was an error while executing `VBoxManage`, a CLI used by Vagrant
for controlling VirtualBox. The command and stderr is shown below.

Command: ["startvm", "145b5aec-b9c5-4feb-9728-e8670bb71b48", "--type",
"headless"]

Stderr: VBoxManage: error: The specified string / bytes buffer was to
small. Specify a larger one and retry. (VERR_CFGM_NOT_ENOUGH_SPACE)
VBoxManage: error: Details: code NS_ERROR_FAILURE (0x80004005),
component ConsoleWrap, interface IConsole

[1] https://github.com/hashicorp/vagrant/issues/9524

Change-Id: Id10cd882b08d9ca9ec661c280d8549fa13af6243

subject: Allow user to specify password for Redis connection
messages:
[{'account_id': 5950, 'date': '2018-05-17 09:53:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5950, 'date': '2018-05-18 08:43:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Steps to verify:
0) Get or set Redis password (/etc/redis.conf, parameter `requirepass`)
1) Update configuration of services and include password into connection string, e.g.:
   connection_string = redis://:SECRET@localhost:6379
2) Restart services
3) export OSPROFILER_HMAC_KEY=SECRET_KEY
   export OSPROFILER_CONNECTION_STRING=redis://:SECRET@localhost:6379
4) Create a trace with e.g.
   openstack --os-profile $OSPROFILER_HMAC_KEY flavor list
5) Get list of traces:
   osprofiler trace list --connection-string $OSPROFILER_CONNECTION_STRING
6) Get a trace:
   osprofiler trace show --connection-string $OSPROFILER_CONNECTION_STRING --html <trace-id>'}, {'account_id': 26598, 'date': '2018-05-18 13:29:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Allow user to specify password for Redis connection

Support full schema for connection to Redis: make port number
optional, allow password and database number. The schema is following:
`redis://[:password]@host[:port][/db]`

Change-Id: I0f8be615aa95409653211b24e114d8b0870b2afa
Closes-Bug: #1768742

[{'created': '2018-06-05 03:58:50.000000000', 'message': "Use tox for grafyaml validation

Currently this calls out to grafyaml-validate.sh which tries to
install zuul-cloner and then pull grafyaml from that.

Since zuulv3 doesn't *have* zuul-cloner, this means the job is broken
for local testing.  It works in the gate only because zuul-cloner
compatability shims are installed.

To maintain the testing-against-master behaviour, the dependent change
provides the grafyaml source in the environment; otherwise we go to
git directly.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/572251
Change-Id: I3d5cd062414b77aaa70d2669730fda870ca0168e
"}]
commit_message:
Use tox for grafyaml validation

Currently this calls out to grafyaml-validate.sh which tries to
install zuul-cloner and then pull grafyaml from that.

Since zuulv3 doesn't *have* zuul-cloner, this means the job is broken
for local testing.  It works in the gate only because zuul-cloner
compatability shims are installed.

To maintain the testing-against-master behaviour, the dependent change
provides the grafyaml source in the environment; otherwise we go to
git directly.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/572251
Change-Id: I3d5cd062414b77aaa70d2669730fda870ca0168e

commit_message:
project-config-grafyaml: pass source to tox

This job wants to run grafyaml from master (which is what happens on
the grafana server, as it installs from current git).  Pass the
grafyaml checkout so it can do this.

Change-Id: I57211ba4041bd567ad9e3134382c0ebd353da267
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/572083

commit_message:
Import nova CLI reference from openstack-manuals

This replaces the old CLI reference main page for
the various nova commands with the more complete
CLI reference that was in the openstack-manuals
report based on the "before-migration" tag in
that repo, which was the tag before the centralized
docs were dropped in Pike and should have been
moved into per-project repos, in this case
python-novaclient.

The command reference in here is a bit old and
should be cleaned up, but this is better than
what we have today, which is nothing.

Change-Id: If19cfcafc90fddb930c124a5b9845d4eae1f6093
Closes-Bug: #1775281

[{'created': '2018-06-05 21:36:25.000000000', 'message': 'Add galera_address to list of variables

Previously, we had a <service>_galera_address for every project,
however, it looks like the patches to move the creation of the
database inside the roles have worked great, but their testing
patches inside this repo. have dropped the usage of the address
which means that the service is configured with 127.0.0.1 (the
fallback if none is provided).

This patch fixes this by adding that variable so that everything
can go through smoothly.  Therefore, the removal of future
<service>_galera_address variables will not affect things.

Change-Id: Ib180fc3a7cbae28b413094b444f7d528b584c9ed
'}]
commit_message:
Add galera_address to list of variables

Previously, we had a <service>_galera_address for every project,
however, it looks like the patches to move the creation of the
database inside the roles have worked great, but their testing
patches inside this repo. have dropped the usage of the address
which means that the service is configured with 127.0.0.1 (the
fallback if none is provided).

This patch fixes this by adding that variable so that everything
can go through smoothly.  Therefore, the removal of future
<service>_galera_address variables will not affect things.

Change-Id: Ib180fc3a7cbae28b413094b444f7d528b584c9ed

commit_message:
Use HMAC.hexdigest to avoid non-ascii characters for package data

hmac.compare_digest() method in python 3 doesn't suppport non-ASCII
characters, so that we need to use HMAC.hexdigest() to avoid non-ASCII
bytes.

For backward compability, we still need to support HMAC created by
using HMAC.digest() in the old amphorae.

commit_message:
Use HMAC.hexdigest to avoid non-ascii characters for package data

hmac.compare_digest() method in python 3 doesn't suppport non-ASCII
characters, so that we need to use HMAC.hexdigest() to avoid non-ASCII
bytes.

For backward compability, we still need to support HMAC created by
using HMAC.digest() in the old amphorae.

Change-Id: I1061e855d0ce06d91a26d217291008197e4a708b
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/567688/
Story: 2002125
Task: 19807
(cherry picked from commit fdc96d9d9e334c501c1a6b168cacd8e4ca2702a4)

commit_message:
Improve Health Manager error handling

It was reported that the Health Manager process could be crashed with
malformed heartbeat packets. I was unable to reproduce the issue
(I suspect oslo_utils fixed the root cause), but I could see how this
could happen and our error handling could be improved.
This is a lower severity as this port is intended to be only accessible
from a private lb-mgmt-net network.
This patch adds additional exception handling to the Health Manager
listener routines to better handle heartbeat packet issues.

Change-Id: I2da6fa394f5152148237d0986fd969b7950815ba
Story: 2001959
Task: 15081
(cherry picked from commit 8e2f7512c2c6b06b6f284edb7cfc6f548ae1085b)

commit_message:
Enable VM communication channel for power management

This spec aims to introduce some support for network operators using VNF
that require to balance power and performance. Power consumption can be
modulated by leveraging HW power features and controls (e.g. frequency
scaling) depending on the traffic load, allowing for management and
costs advantages.

A communication channel has to be enabled at VM boot time for the VNF to
control such HW features via a power governor (agent) running on the
host.

Change-Id: Ia0677276b0cd512bec3fb5b548e7c19802f1bc56

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-31 10:16:40.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: handle DiskNotFound during update_available_resource

The update_available_resource periodic task in the compute manager
eventually calls through to the resource tracker and virt driver
get_available_resource method, which gets the guests running on
the hypervisor, and builds up a set of information about the host.
This includes disk information for the active domains.

However, the periodic task can race with instances being deleted
concurrently and the hypervisor can report the domain but the driver
has already deleted the backing files as part of deleting the
instance, and this leads to failures when running "qemu-img info"
on the disk path which is now gone.

When that happens, the entire periodic update fails.

This change simply tries to detect the specific failure from
'qemu-img info' and translate it into a DiskNotFound exception which
the driver can handle. In this case, if the associated instance is
undergoing a task state transition such as moving to another host or
being deleted, we log a message and continue. If the instance is in
steady state (task_state is not set), then we consider it a failure
and re-raise it up.

Note that we could add the deleted=False filter to the instance query
in _get_disk_over_committed_size_total but that doesn't help us in
this case because the hypervisor says the domain is still active
and the instance is not actually considered deleted in the DB yet.

Conflicts:
        nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py

NOTE(lyarwood): Simple logging conflicts caused by the removal of _LI
and _LW during Pike.

Change-Id: Icec2769bf42455853cbe686fb30fda73df791b25
Closes-Bug: #1662867
(cherry picked from commit 5f16e714f58336344752305f94451e7c7c55742c)
(cherry picked from commit 5a4c6913a37f912489543abd5e12a54feeeb89e2)
(cherry picked from commit d251b95083731829ba104dc5c7f642dd5097d510)
'}, {'created': '2018-06-01 16:02:21.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: handle DiskNotFound during update_available_resource

on the disk path which is now gone.

When that happens, the entire periodic update fails.

This change simply tries to detect the specific failure from
'qemu-img info' and translate it into a DiskNotFound exception which
the driver can handle. In this case, if the associated instance is
undergoing a task state transition such as moving to another host or
being deleted, we log a message and continue. If the instance is in
steady state (task_state is not set), then we consider it a failure
and re-raise it up.

Note that we could add the deleted=False filter to the instance query

and the instance is not actually considered deleted in the DB yet.

Conflicts:
        nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py
        nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py

NOTE(lyarwood): Conflicts due to the substantial refactoring of
_get_instance_disk_info via I9616a602ee0605f7f1dc1f47b6416f01895e025b
and removal of _LW etc during Pike,

Change-Id: Icec2769bf42455853cbe686fb30fda73df791b25
Closes-Bug: #1662867
(cherry picked from commit 5f16e714f58336344752305f94451e7c7c55742c)
(cherry picked from commit 5a4c6913a37f912489543abd5e12a54feeeb89e2)
(cherry picked from commit d251b95083731829ba104dc5c7f642dd5097d510)

commit_message:
libvirt: handle DiskNotFound during update_available_resource

The update_available_resource periodic task in the compute manager
eventually calls through to the resource tracker and virt driver
get_available_resource method, which gets the guests running on
the hypervisor, and builds up a set of information about the host.
This includes disk information for the active domains.

However, the periodic task can race with instances being deleted
concurrently and the hypervisor can report the domain but the driver
has already deleted the backing files as part of deleting the
instance, and this leads to failures when running "qemu-img info"
on the disk path which is now gone.

When that happens, the entire periodic update fails.

This change simply tries to detect the specific failure from
'qemu-img info' and translate it into a DiskNotFound exception which
the driver can handle. In this case, if the associated instance is
undergoing a task state transition such as moving to another host or
being deleted, we log a message and continue. If the instance is in
steady state (task_state is not set), then we consider it a failure
and re-raise it up.

Note that we could add the deleted=False filter to the instance query
in _get_disk_over_committed_size_total but that doesn't help us in
this case because the hypervisor says the domain is still active
and the instance is not actually considered deleted in the DB yet.

Conflicts:
        nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py
        nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py

NOTE(lyarwood): Conflicts due to the substantial refactoring of
_get_instance_disk_info via I9616a602ee0605f7f1dc1f47b6416f01895e025b
and removal of _LW etc during Pike,

Change-Id: Icec2769bf42455853cbe686fb30fda73df791b25
Closes-Bug: #1662867
(cherry picked from commit 5f16e714f58336344752305f94451e7c7c55742c)
(cherry picked from commit 5a4c6913a37f912489543abd5e12a54feeeb89e2)
(cherry picked from commit d251b95083731829ba104dc5c7f642dd5097d510)

This is less comment on this change - I'm fine with it. I have no qualms with this as the default people get - most installs of this are on VMs and laptops and production will require some extra care -- I am concerned we will no longer forcefully validate HA functionality. especially given L3 HA has been bug laden in the past. There is a strong emphasis for this project to focus on providing something that will work for a production installation.  If we are stripping these away from the default overrides, will we be crafting an "HA" gate to be validating we can turn these on successfully? As an example, imagine our OOTB containers (for some reason) are missing keepalived or the appropriate root-wrap settings to call it; we wouldn't be catching this without enabling HA.'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2018-05-25 19:19:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow-1

> This is less comment on this change - I'm fine with it. I have no
 > qualms with this as the default people get - most installs of this

 > If we are stripping these away from the default overrides, will we
 > be crafting an "HA" gate to be validating we can turn these on
 > successfully? As an example, imagine our OOTB containers (for some
 > reason) are missing keepalived or the appropriate root-wrap
 > settings to call it; we wouldn't be catching this without enabling
 > HA.

good points and we've been bitten by this before with mariadb and also rabbit settings

how about i leave this -WF for now until we can validate the multi-node gate is doing most of what we expect it to?'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2018-06-05 18:31:04.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow-1 by Chris Wedgwood <cw@f00f.org>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-05 12:14:06.000000000', 'message': 'Bump minor version of mariadb

This bumps the mariadb version, by adding a new repo.
As the package state is by default to "latest", the
addition of the new repo will trigger an upgrade
of the mariadb version.

Change-Id: I43e6cde7e83f62ec8fe0bb7d487c911382f6033b
'}]
commit_message:
Bump minor version of mariadb

This bumps the mariadb version, by adding a new repo.
As the package state is by default to "latest", the
addition of the new repo will trigger an upgrade
of the mariadb version.

Change-Id: I43e6cde7e83f62ec8fe0bb7d487c911382f6033b

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/lower-constraints.txt'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-05-29 21:52:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-05-29 21:52:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Patch Set 10 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 13557, 'date': '2018-05-29 21:56:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

LGTM, though perhaps lower-constraints / test-requirements could use a haircut?

Maybe that's something for a different patch."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-05-29 22:31:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-05-29 22:31:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Patch Set 12 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-05-30 01:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-06-04 02:50:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-06-04 21:24:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

I think mdrabe had a good point and we should make our lower-constraints.txt align with nova. The only differences I'd expect are additions for packages we require but nova doesn't (or required by such packages). But besides those additions we should a) list everything nova does and b) list the same version nova lists when we both list something."}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-06-05 06:18:51.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Nguyen Hai with the following votes:

* Code-Review+1 by Nguyen Hai <nguyentrihai93@gmail.com>
'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-05 14:20:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-05 14:22:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Patch Set 14 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-06-05 17:14:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2

(5 comments)

Our requirements.txt includes amqp whereas nova's does not and therefore nova's lower-constraints.txt doesn't include that. So we should really include amqp in the lower-constraints.txt we use here ... or remove it from our requirements.txt if it's not really needed. And I can't see any reason that it's needed, so maybe that's the right approach. That can probably be a follow-on.

Some of our test-requirements are also not in nova's lower-constraints.txt. But I'm not sure we should be so concerned about them if they're just test-requirements. May need some follow-on work, but I won't hold this up for that."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-05 17:24:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

> 
 > Some of our test-requirements are also not in nova's
 > lower-constraints.txt. But I'm not sure we should be so concerned
 > about them if they're just test-requirements. May need some
 > follow-on work, but I won't hold this up for that.

It sounds like maybe the requirements check job should be looking at the test requirements when validating lower-constraints.txt, too. If you're interested in helping with that enhancement let me know and I'll help you get started."}, {'account_id': 13557, 'date': '2018-06-05 21:25:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

The nova-powervm project uses Nova's lower-constraints.txt file; it
doesn't need its own.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I637abb9624bf237ef2e1e70bf40bb1d64e77d354
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Fix listener update race with default pool removal
messages:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-05 08:48:42.000000000', 'message': 'Fix listener update race with default pool removal

If the listener-api code updates the DB before the controller-worker
code for the update executes (this seems very common) and the update is
removing a default pool, then the pool is already gone from the object
before we get to that point in the amp-driver.

Change-Id: If06141ef2328608c019594852a3ded3872b8a51d
(cherry picked from commit 1bcd5ef4b28eb022d520b0eb15ad6750c6bf02fb)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix listener update race with default pool removal

If the listener-api code updates the DB before the controller-worker
code for the update executes (this seems very common) and the update is
removing a default pool, then the pool is already gone from the object
before we get to that point in the amp-driver.

Change-Id: If06141ef2328608c019594852a3ded3872b8a51d
(cherry picked from commit 1bcd5ef4b28eb022d520b0eb15ad6750c6bf02fb)

commit_message:
Fix upgrade scripts for missing OVS functions

OVS 2.9 introduced several workarounds for upgrade. These functions
weren't properly included into the generated scripts.

Change-Id: I823c9e3db9b065fddd297e6bbdd1b51a9c7501d1
Resolves: rhbz#1582332
Closes-Bug: #1773822

subject: Add StarlingX repos
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 970, 'name': 'Dean Troyer', 'email': 'dtroyer@gmail.com', 'username': 'dtroyer'}, {'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 4162, 'name': 'Paul Belanger', 'email': 'pabelanger@redhat.com', 'username': 'pabelanger'}, {'_account_id': 5263, 'name': 'Jeremy Stanley', 'display_name': 'fungi', 'email': 'fungi@yuggoth.org', 'username': 'fungi', 'status': 'missing, presumed fed'}, {'_account_id': 6547, 'name': 'Andreas Jaeger', 'email': 'jaegerandi@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaegerandi'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 21723, 'name': 'Gergely Csatari', 'email': 'gergely.csatari@nokia.com', 'username': 'csatari'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-19 07:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-19 10:16:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I’m more than a little uneasy about the idea of us hosting forks of our own projects.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-05-19 11:24:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If they use the track-upstream option they can at least rebase onto or merge from actual OpenStack service repos without having to push in their own copies of upstream commits as new changes in Gerrit. Another alternative might be to get the corresponding upstream repos to carry a feature/starlingx branch instead so we don't end up with separate repos for all of these, but that will likely require a lot of convincing."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-19 14:04:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Doug, you are not alone, and I share the concern. And I wish we would have had the opportunity to have these conversations long before this.

The goal is to get all of the changes we are currently carrying merged into their upstreams, the reality is that they will not all be accepted, certainly not with any sort of speed.  We are starting with a shipping product and are including everything in the intial release.  This code needs to be available somewhere in order to build.

One other option is to just include a massive squash of the upstream code rather than a complete history.  With my dev hat on I hate that idea, especially if I'm working on upstreaming these patches or rebasing on a new release (there are another set of problems here that we can talk about elsewhere).

What else can we do to help reassure that these are not meant to be forks, either in appearance or in practice?"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-05-19 15:35:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I haven't dived deep into this (nor had the opportunity to discuss it with Dean yet) but it appears like this is an edge-oriented distribution of OpenStack. Like most distros, they carry a set of patches. As long as the intention is to upstream as many of those patches as possible, I think we are on the right path. I would not be surprised if we ended up with a set of non-acceptable-upstream patches that are linked to the use case (edge vs. datacenter cloud), and that would be OK for me as well.

Now maybe a better way to approach this would be to maintain the delta as a set of discrete patches rather than full repos -- it's a little weirder but it makes upstreaming easier (and looks less like "a fork") .

Looking forward to discussing this in more detail with Dean this week.'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-05-19 16:34:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree with others here, when we had the Debian packaging hosted on openstack-infra, it too was carrying duplicated code from upstream repos. At a minimum, we want to use the track-upstream option fungi points out.

I'd much rather see any patches stx needs to carry, as git-diff files in tree, which fits well into the packaging model (eg: RPM or dpkg)"}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-05-19 16:44:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

While git diff files will certainly yield more efficient storage in cases like this, they add more steps for collaborators (both those altering and those reviewing in-tree diffs) to export/import them. So this suggestion trades human efficiency for systems efficiency, a choice which should not be taken lightly.'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-05-19 16:58:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Agree, that would be my preference, but acknowledge I'm not the one writing code. it would also be helpful to better understand why patches can't be merged upstream. Look forward to discussions at summit this week."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-19 17:36:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

I should have the import repos ready today so you'll be able to see them, I just got the final approval to push the code about an hour ago.  The timing is certainly sub-optimal...

I've started a q&a in https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/stx-faq hopefully that sheds a bit of light too on the background.

ttx: yes, this is aimed at edge and for the edge focus area.

re carrying patch files, we have talked about that, and there are a LOT of those in stx-upstream for packages with a small number of changes (like tweaking versioning to make rpm happy).  It is a PITA for developers and why I don't want to go there first but it does set a different tone on first reading.

About merging upstream, some have, some have been proposed and some have been rejected.  and some were for things that have been been implemented upstream and will be removed once we base on queens or later. This project started on kilo, if not earlier so there are some things kept for compatibility reasons.

I would love to drive these to zero, and in fact we have removed a number of repos that no longer needed to carry patches.  There is also a long list of what we think can be successfully merged upstream.  We have already had help from regular Intel OpenStack contributors in reviewing the changes and sorting out priorities.  Biggest example there is dlyle extracting much of the Horizon work into a plugin (later to be multiple plugins)."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-19 18:12:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-19 18:18:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Import URLs are in place...actual code will be there later today.

I do have a content-related question for this.  Being new-ish to setting up projects for Storyboard, my intention is to have a single group of Storyboard projects for the primary StarlingX repos.

I am sure there would be a concern that not setting up the upstream repos that things will get reported to the actual upstreams that belong here?  I know that I would want bugs for a modified OSC to go to the modifiers first and let them decide if it needs to come up. What I do not know is the likely hood of that happening in a Storyboard setup.

What is the best way to set that up in Storyboard?  Use a second group for them maybe?
I have them set to not set up storyboard for now until this gets sorted.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-19 18:36:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-05-19 20:21:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

SB supports placing projects in an arbitrary number of groups. I would recommend having at least one group which has all the repos the SX team is going to care about tracking, but you can also put a subset of those in an additional group if that helps (c.f., the overlap between the "interop" and "refstack" project groups on sb.o.o).'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-20 10:47:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-20 21:55:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-21 04:47:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-21 06:17:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-23 06:08:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-05-29 14:05:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Few things to look at.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-30 21:13:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-05-31 22:24:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-06-01 15:21:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

really sorry I missed those the first run..'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-06-01 15:22:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: -Code-Review

use-storyboard: false, sorry, forget my comment'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-06-05 13:48:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-June/131159.html'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-06-05 18:21:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Btw. groups can be used for launchpad as well. If the file is correct, please mention this in the commit message so that we know it is intentional.

Change itself looks fine otherwise'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-06-05 20:00:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Fine, there's heartburn over utility repos not being on Storyboard, I'll add them..."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-06-05 20:00:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-06-05 20:02:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-06-05 20:58:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-19 07:22:53.000000000', 'message': "Add StarlingX repos

WIP - needs upstream repo URLs

StarlingX is the open source release of WindRiver's (WRS) Titanium Cloud.
Titanium is a turnkey cloud deployment based around CentOS, OpenStack, Ceph
and libvirt+Qemu.  It is highly tuned for edge network performance and
commercially aimed at telco and industrial deployments.

There are two groups of git repos associated with StarlingX:
* new projects that provide services such as high availability, fault
  management, installation/upgrades/patching
* modifications to upstream projects that have not been merged by the
  upstream projects

StarlingX repos
stx-clients - client libraries
stx-config - Configuration Management
stx-fault - Fault Management
stx-gplv2 - GPLv2 licensed upstream packages
stx-gplv3 - GPLv3 licensed upstream packages
stx-gui - Horizon plugins for new services
stx-ha - High Availability/Service Management
stx-integ - Integration and packaging
stx-metal - Bare Metal Management
stx-nfv - NFVI Orchestration
stx-root - build tools
stx-update - Installation/Update/Patching
stx-upstream - Upstream packages
stx-utils - utilities, logging

Upstream repos
stx-ceilometer
stx-ceph
stx-cinder
stx-glance

stx-horizon

"}, {'created': '2018-05-19 18:12:36.000000000', 'message': "Add StarlingX repos

StarlingX is the open source release of Wind River's (WRS) Titanium
Cloud.  Titanium is an integrated virtualization platform based
around OpenStack, Ceph, libvirt+Qemu and CentOS.  It is tuned to
provide quality-of-service and low-latency network performance with
carrier-grade service uptime, commercially aimed at telco and
industrial edge deployments.

There are two groups of git repos associated with StarlingX:
* New projects that provide services and REST APIs to support services
  such as high availability, fault management,
  installation/upgrades/patching, backup and restore.
* Modifications to upstream projects that have not yet been merged
  by those projects.  The goal is to reduce these patches to zero,
  the reality is there are likely some to be carried for a time
  longer than we like.

Additional background and Q&A is in https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/stx-faq

StarlingX repos
stx-clients - client libraries
stx-config - Configuration Management
stx-fault - Fault Management
stx-gplv2 - GPLv2 licensed upstream packages
stx-gplv3 - GPLv3 licensed upstream packages
stx-gui - Horizon plugins for new services

stx-integ - Integration and packaging

"}, {'created': '2018-05-20 10:47:40.000000000', 'message': "Add StarlingX repos

StarlingX is the open source release of Wind River's (WRS) Titanium
Cloud.  Titanium is an integrated virtualization platform based
around OpenStack, Ceph, libvirt+Qemu and CentOS.  It is tuned to
provide quality-of-service and low-latency network performance with
carrier-grade service uptime, commercially aimed at telco and
industrial edge deployments.

There are two groups of git repos associated with StarlingX:
* New projects that provide services and REST APIs to support services
  such as high availability, fault management,
  installation/upgrades/patching, backup and restore.
* Modifications to upstream projects that have not yet been merged
  by those projects.  The goal is to reduce these patches to zero,
  the reality is there are likely some to be carried for a time
  longer than we like.

Additional background and Q&A is in https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/stx-faq

StarlingX repos
stx-clients - client libraries
stx-config - Configuration Management
stx-fault - Fault Management
stx-gplv2 - GPLv2 licensed upstream packages
stx-gplv3 - GPLv3 licensed upstream packages
stx-gui - Horizon plugins for new services
stx-ha - High Availability/Service Management
stx-integ - Integration and packaging
stx-manifest - source manifest to manage the repositories
stx-metal - Bare Metal Management
stx-nfv - NFVI Orchestration
stx-root - build source tree root
stx-tools - build tools
stx-update - Installation/Update/Patching
stx-upstream - Upstream packages
stx-utils - utilities, logging
stx-3rdparty-repo - build support
stx-centos-repo - build support
stx-tis-repo - build support

Upstream repos

commit_message:
Add StarlingX repos

StarlingX is the open source release of Wind River's (WRS) Titanium
Cloud.  Titanium is an integrated virtualization platform based
around OpenStack, Ceph, libvirt+Qemu and CentOS.  It is tuned to
provide quality-of-service and low-latency network performance with
carrier-grade service uptime, commercially aimed at telco and
industrial edge deployments.

These repos are new projects that provide services and REST APIs to
support services such as high availability, fault management,
installation/upgrades/patching, backup and restore.

Additional background and Q&A is in https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/stx-faq

StarlingX repos
stx-clients - client libraries
stx-config - Configuration Management
stx-fault - Fault Management
stx-gplv2 - GPLv2 licensed upstream packages
stx-gplv3 - GPLv3 licensed upstream packages
stx-gui - Horizon plugins for new services
stx-ha - High Availability/Service Management
stx-integ - Integration and packaging
stx-manifest - source manifest to manage the repositories
stx-metal - Bare Metal Management
stx-nfv - NFVI Orchestration
stx-root - build source tree root
stx-tools - build tools
stx-update - Installation/Update/Patching
stx-upstream - Upstream packages
stx-utils - utilities, logging
stx-tis-repo - build support

Story: 2002123
Change-Id: I6137abc6c967cf69d69c7643eb227d54acb37f37

commit_message:
(do-not-merge!) hack to point to neutron-lib git

This is a hack to allow testing changes stacked on this one
with neutron-lib change Id5aea04553b78dd17fca85de88cf076b42d24140.

The Depends-On magic does not work when neutron-lib is not
declared in zuul job 'required-projects' attribute.

Change-Id: I2ff5123e50e29804b8bf454be4b3a08a1f37dd92

commit_message:
Use override pip_upstream_url for get-pip

The I693b930bf337fd08931d835d57ffe9ecae904517 introduces the new
issue on environments where https://bootstrap.pypa.io not reachable
and overrided by pip_upstream_url setting.

Change-Id: I79d95f0efff4af41850de39632a95a6b6a7dc933
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2018-06-05 14:13:43.000000000', 'message': "Create distutils cfg before install and build

Some old Python2 pip sources still use setup.py, so when you provide
your own index sources via repo_build_pip_default_index the 'Download
requirement pip sources' task might fail while trying to reach a
default external PyPI index URL.

Change-Id: Ib7d2a9aee9b13f38b73136f22f0b51e766c8dd10
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Create distutils cfg before install and build

Some old Python2 pip sources still use setup.py, so when you provide
your own index sources via repo_build_pip_default_index the 'Download
requirement pip sources' task might fail while trying to reach a
default external PyPI index URL.

Change-Id: Ib7d2a9aee9b13f38b73136f22f0b51e766c8dd10
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

avoid creating a server group with no policies.

[{'account_id': 17280, 'date': '2018-06-04 20:26:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17280, 'date': '2018-06-04 20:29:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

This change actually breaks the file because of bad spacing inside the loop:
https://gist.github.com/trozet/46d712df01271a0e9032f9e14082242d#file-allnodesconfig_templatedata-log-L201

Actually quite a hard error to detect, because heat gives a bad error message saying:
Property error: resources.allNodesConfig.properties: Unknown Property controller_ips"

This is because heat raises a ValueError when yaml parsing fails, but the parent methods in heat catch the ValueError and ignore it.  going to file a bug on that.  However when you insert some print statements inside of heat you can see the load error:
https://gist.github.com/trozet/8b901f2234dcbf3e2290d213c0b16561'}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-06-04 20:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

If we don't cleanup the DCD files during the undercloud upgrade,
RabbitMQ will start with old credentials and OpenStack services won't be
able to connect to the AMQP.

Note: we only do this task when upgrading to a containerized undercloud,
therefore there is no impact on overcloud.

Closes-Bug: #1774927

commit_message:
rabbitmq: cleanup .DCD files during undercloud upgrade

If we don't cleanup the DCD files during the undercloud upgrade,
RabbitMQ will start with old credentials and OpenStack services won't be
able to connect to the AMQP.

Note: we only do this task when upgrading to a containerized undercloud,
therefore there is no impact on overcloud.

Change-Id: I9f8a9cecd5566f1a7ef6bd301cf57424a99a4920
Closes-Bug: #1774927

commit_message:
Update blueprint link in default roles specification

The link for the blueprint was pointing 404'ing because it was
pointing to a different namespace. This commit updates the
specification to point to the the blueprint tracked within
keystone for the default roles work.

Change-Id: I6a22dcc81c382a7e9ce559b7bf8bda2685023b87

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-31 12:40:08.000000000', 'message': 'Remove explicit fsid charm config option

The charm has had the capability to automatically handle fsid
in deployments for several cycles.

Explicitly setting the fsid can lead to unpredictable behavior
when data from previous deployments remains on block devices,
and when the fsid is explicitly static across those separate
deployments.  ex. Ceph would see the fsid match and attempt to
use the block device from a previous deployment as-is and
unsuccessfully.

This primarily affects legacy development and CI environments,
which may be in place from a time before the charm autoatically
handled fsids.  The recommendation is for both test and production
deployments to defer fsid generation to the charm.

Change-Id: I0b87576810faa08a81dc2d559ef925ea02f58db0
Partial-bug: #1698154
'}, {'created': '2018-05-31 13:34:44.000000000', 'message': 'Remove explicit fsid charm config option

This primarily affects legacy development and CI environments,
which may be in place from a time before the charm autoatically

unsuccessfully.

This primarily affects legacy development and CI environments,
which may be in place from a time before the charm autoatically
handled fsids.  The recommendation is for both test and production
deployments to defer fsid generation to the charm.

Change-Id: I0b87576810faa08a81dc2d559ef925ea02f58db0

commit_message:
Remove explicit fsid charm config option

The charm has had the capability to automatically handle fsid
in deployments for several cycles.

Explicitly setting the fsid can lead to unpredictable behavior
when data from previous deployments remains on block devices,
and when the fsid is explicitly static across those separate
deployments.  ex. Ceph would see the fsid match and attempt to
use the block device from a previous deployment as-is and
unsuccessfully.

This primarily affects legacy development and CI environments,
which may be in place from a time before the charm autoatically
handled fsids.  The recommendation is for both test and production
deployments to defer fsid generation to the charm.

Change-Id: I0b87576810faa08a81dc2d559ef925ea02f58db0
Partial-bug: #1698154

commit_message:
Fix vcpu override var issue for logging hostvar.

loadbalancer_vm_server_vcpus is used instead of logging_vm_server_vcpus
for the vcpu override host_vars/logging1.yml file.  This review is to
correct the naming error.

Change-Id: I7f335eb8c8baf84ecc122abcba4c315512794b4a
Closes-Bug: 1775211

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-31 00:41:28.000000000', 'message': "Fix handling of 'cinder_encryption_key_id' image metadata

The Cinder code that processes Glance image metadata
is a bit confused about whether this particular field
is a Glance property or metadata.

Since it isn't a defined a Glance property and is stored
in image metadata, ensure that Cinder also tracks it
metadata and not as a property.

This mismatch prior to this fix causes Cinder to create
volumes with the wrong encryption key when creating a
volume from an encrypted image, which results in an
unreadable volume.

Closes-Bug: #1764125
Change-Id: Ie5af3703eaa82d23b50127f611235d86e4104369
(cherry picked from commit 2792be3ffced9b7faeb69fa100b3c50b76d00dc3)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix handling of 'cinder_encryption_key_id' image metadata

The Cinder code that processes Glance image metadata
is a bit confused about whether this particular field
is a Glance property or metadata.

Since it isn't a defined a Glance property and is stored
in image metadata, ensure that Cinder also tracks it
metadata and not as a property.

This mismatch prior to this fix causes Cinder to create
volumes with the wrong encryption key when creating a
volume from an encrypted image, which results in an
unreadable volume.

Closes-Bug: #1764125
Change-Id: Ie5af3703eaa82d23b50127f611235d86e4104369
(cherry picked from commit 2792be3ffced9b7faeb69fa100b3c50b76d00dc3)

commit_message:
Fix listing of instances above API max_limit

Output of `nova list` command contained only `max_limit` entries even
when there were more. The list needs to be obtained in multiple
requests and the paging loop was terminated prematurely.

Change-Id: I4194e6d5e34ecc0ac704851c08bb895e223aa850
Closes-Bug: 1743532

commit_message:
Fix documentation error

There was a mistake in an earlier patch where
'snapshot' was used instead of 'volume'.  This
follow-up patch corrects the wording.

Change-Id: Ib1a03521c277c12d1b7f1c91eb1f2df1972e883f

[{'created': '2018-06-05 13:42:55.000000000', 'message': "Variable node address

This adds a var similar to what we have in the galera_server role [1],
making the local node's incoming address a var. This allows the
role's consumer to define a different node address than the one used

Change-Id: I30e51668545095c8f6d91902516767d7bf158202

This adds a var similar to what we have in the galera_server role [1],
making the local node's incoming address a var. This allows the
role's consumer to define a different node address than the one used
by ansible in ansible_host.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server/blob/master/defaults/main.yml#L92

"}]
commit_message:
Variable node address

This adds a var similar to what we have in the galera_server role [1],
making the local node's incoming address a var. This allows the
role's consumer to define a different node address than the one used
by ansible in ansible_host.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server/blob/master/defaults/main.yml#L92

Change-Id: I30e51668545095c8f6d91902516767d7bf158202

commit_message:
undercloud: enable KernelIpNonLocalBind

We need KernelIpNonLocalBind on the undercloud to bind non local ips
among other ip forward options. This sysctl parameter was managed by
instack-undercloud but never ported to the containerized undercloud.
We need the same sysctl parameters for parity with non containerized
undercloud.

Change-Id: Idd3d432b8f7eb573d94cd56be8e05614510ebddf
Related-Bug: #1774898

commit_message:
Switch to use primary credential in volume backup tests

Not all the apis in tempest/api/volume/admin/test_volumes_backup.py
should use admin credential, some apis could switch to use primary
credential. See [1].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/policies/backups.py

Change-Id: Ied77f68c982f3a8445956ad1a4ea47c3795d3294

subject: Fix empty kolla_overcloud_inventory_storage_groups
messages:
[{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-05-25 11:43:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 18368, 'date': '2018-06-01 12:07:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2018-06-05 16:25:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-06-05 17:15:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck

keystone failure'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-25 11:43:00.000000000', 'message': "Fix empty kolla_overcloud_inventory_storage_groups

In some cases we may have a kolla group defined in
'kolla_overcloud_inventory_top_level_group_map' which has no kayobe
groups mapped to it. This causes no entry to be added to the inventory
for the group.  If the group is referenced elsewhere in the inventory,
then Ansible will fail to parse the inventory file.

The specific case that failed was when setting
'kolla_overcloud_inventory_storage_groups' to an empty list.

This change ensures that we add an empty definition for the group in the
kolla inventory.

Change-Id: I8e797aa6c55f8cf0cf6d52a33f213d8131581fea
Story: 2002105
Task: 19783
"}]
commit_message:
Fix empty kolla_overcloud_inventory_storage_groups

In some cases we may have a kolla group defined in
'kolla_overcloud_inventory_top_level_group_map' which has no kayobe
groups mapped to it. This causes no entry to be added to the inventory
for the group.  If the group is referenced elsewhere in the inventory,
then Ansible will fail to parse the inventory file.

The specific case that failed was when setting
'kolla_overcloud_inventory_storage_groups' to an empty list.

This change ensures that we add an empty definition for the group in the
kolla inventory.

Change-Id: I8e797aa6c55f8cf0cf6d52a33f213d8131581fea
Story: 2002105

commit_message:
Add keystone only upgrade jobs

Using featureset051 it will do an upgrade of scenario000 (keystone only).

Depends-On: Iad86a5910434c6e69eb1eaa6c51311b112ed17ab
Depends-On: I4a4e769b07e1982e83cbaec6651c215666def83d
Change-Id: I4d8ad33d5dc399a9172370663ca3aa7e93f1a973

The failure looks to be bugs in ODL and networking-odl:

https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=8926
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1477516

We need to get the following logs in order to debug the ODL bug:
On each controller node:
/opt/opendaylight/log/data/ folder (contains ODL logs)
'rpm -q opendaylight'
on every node:
'ovs-ofctl -O openflow13 dump-flows br-int' 
'ovs-ofctl -O openflow13 show br-int'
'ovs-vsctl show'"}, {'account_id': 11240, 'date': '2017-08-15 20:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

What does the deployment look like - bridges, external, provider networks, etc? Any bridges created before connecting to ODL?

In addition what what Tim requested add the following:

ovs-ofctl -OOpenFlow13 show br-int
ovs-ofctl -OOpenFlow13 dump-groups br-int
ovs-ofctl -OOpenFlow13 dump-group-states br-int
ovs-vsctl list Open_vSwitch

ip link
ip -o addr
arp -an'}, {'account_id': 6994, 'date': '2017-08-16 00:24:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 6994, 'date': '2017-08-16 00:25:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-04 01:05:06.000000000', 'message': 'Improve Health Manager error handling

It was reported that the Health Manager process could be crashed with
malformed heartbeat packets. I was unable to reproduce the issue
(I suspect oslo_utils fixed the root cause), but I could see how this
could happen and our error handling could be improved.
This is a lower severity as this port is intended to be only accessible
from a private lb-mgmt-net network.
This patch adds additional exception handling to the Health Manager
listener routines to better handle heartbeat packet issues.

Change-Id: I2da6fa394f5152148237d0986fd969b7950815ba
Story: 2001959
Task: 15081
'}]
commit_message:
Improve Health Manager error handling

It was reported that the Health Manager process could be crashed with
malformed heartbeat packets. I was unable to reproduce the issue
(I suspect oslo_utils fixed the root cause), but I could see how this
could happen and our error handling could be improved.
This is a lower severity as this port is intended to be only accessible
from a private lb-mgmt-net network.
This patch adds additional exception handling to the Health Manager
listener routines to better handle heartbeat packet issues.

Change-Id: I2da6fa394f5152148237d0986fd969b7950815ba
Story: 2001959
Task: 15081

subject: Add support to deploy hadoop 2.7.5
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 8932, 'name': 'Telles Mota Vidal Nóbrega', 'email': 'tellesnobrega@gmail.com', 'username': 'tellesnobrega'}, {'_account_id': 10459, 'name': 'Luigi Toscano', 'email': 'ltoscano@redhat.com', 'username': 'ltoscano'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22689, 'name': 'Shu Yingya', 'email': 'yingya.shu@easystack.cn', 'username': 'ShuYingya'}, {'_account_id': 23078, 'name': 'Jeremy Freudberg', 'email': 'jeremyfreudberg@gmail.com', 'username': 'jeremyfreudberg'}, {'_account_id': 27576, 'name': 'Zhuang Changkun', 'email': 'changkun.zhuang@easystack.cn', 'username': 'zchkun'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 27576, 'date': '2018-04-16 12:18:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-04-17 13:14:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I understand that we need to duplicate the resources (so 	sahara/plugins/vanilla/<version>/resources), but maybe we could share a bit more code.

It is true that sahara/plugins/vanilla/v2_8_2 is totally separate from sahara/plugins/vanilla/v2_7_1 and may evolve independently, but maybe some of the code of sahara/plugins/vanilla/v2_7_5/ could be shared with v2_7_1; for example most of config_helper.py and edp_engine.py is the same, apart from the name of the parameter used.

This pattern may be used in the future: for newer versions we could define the version as x.y and let that code handle the differences between x.y.z and x.y.t.'}, {'account_id': 27576, 'date': '2018-04-17 16:01:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree with you, I will try to share the same code to eliminate redundant parts. Thank you.'}, {'account_id': 27576, 'date': '2018-04-19 02:38:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-05-03 18:26:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-05-04 14:17:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I think that we need a release note (with reno).

Also, do you plan a subsequent patch to change the code which handles vanilla 2.7.1 to use vanilla/common/?'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-05-04 16:47:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

I have some readability suggestions - let me know if I can clarify them.

I also agree with Luigi'}, {'account_id': 27576, 'date': '2018-05-07 02:15:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Luigi, this is my idea: the old plugins(such as vanilla 2.7.1) remain unchanged, and the subsequent plugins are based on using vanilla/common/ after.
I'm not sure if we should change all plugins to use vanilla/common/?

And other suggestions that is very useful for me.
Thanks Luigi and Jeremy."}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-05-07 02:25:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

It would be nice if 2.7.1/2.8.2 used common code, too (it might make future bugfixes/changes easier), but it's not really necessary. If we want to do it, it can be done in a followup/separate patch."}, {'account_id': 27576, 'date': '2018-05-07 02:37:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > It would be nice if 2.7.1/2.8.2 used common code, too (it might
 > make future bugfixes/changes easier), but it's not really
 > necessary. If we want to do it, it can be done in a
 > followup/separate patch.

yes, I am also agree with a separate patch to do it."}, {'account_id': 27576, 'date': '2018-05-08 03:04:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-05-15 16:05:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Little thing. Mostly looks good! Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 27576, 'date': '2018-05-16 01:57:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 27576, 'date': '2018-06-01 09:59:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 27576, 'date': '2018-06-01 10:11:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

I adjust the code to the set 1. Next, I want to submit a patch alone to integrate the code, so that the 2.7.x vanilla can share a bit more code, and it will apply to vanilla 3.x.x as well.'}, {'account_id': 27576, 'date': '2018-06-01 10:12:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I adjust the code to the set 1. Next, I want to submit a patch alone to integrate the code, so that the 2.7.x vanilla can share a bit more code, and it will apply to vanilla 3.x.x as well.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-06-05 13:46:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

I'm happy to merge it like this-- with the refactoring (less duplication) to happen later."}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2018-06-05 17:08:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add scenario008 job to include containers

Eventually the non-container scenario008 job will be removed, but for
now it needs to stay until we update all projects that depend on the job
being there and migrate them to container version.

This is part of the work to enable scenario008 as part of check/gate:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/486905/

Change-Id: I33602ac5521c4f059c1a0d08e3e828fb64d3c817
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>

messages: [{'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2018-06-05 16:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-06-05 17:59:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nLGTM'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-05 16:39:55.000000000', 'message': "Fix logic error introduced in assess_status()

Commit 352d6993870be2547f37463e4e3cffc7605f749c introduced a change
in assess_status to not update status as long as the previous status
was 'blocked'.  This was done because the check for pristine block
devices is done elsewhere in the charm.

However there are other situations that might set the charm in
'blocked' state.

This commit addresses this error.

Change-Id: Icdc272dadd7f9ceb670d37238628d31f33d11770
"}]
commit_message:
Fix logic error introduced in assess_status()

Commit 352d6993870be2547f37463e4e3cffc7605f749c introduced a change
in assess_status to not update status as long as the previous status
was 'blocked'.  This was done because the check for pristine block
devices is done elsewhere in the charm.

However there are other situations that might set the charm in
'blocked' state.

This commit addresses this error.

Change-Id: Icdc272dadd7f9ceb670d37238628d31f33d11770

commit_message:
Use inline literal markup for options in releasenotes

This commit makes the releasenotes to use 'inline literal markup[0]
because it would be accurate rendering for commandline
options. Otherwise, dashes are changed into an en/em dash entity. And
this commit also fixes some inline literal markups which I
noticed. Ideally, we should fix like that things in one
patch. However, it's a bit hard to find them all..

[0] http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/basics.html#roles

Change-Id: I8f7691b3ff40ccde051620f44217dab244d76960

[{'created': '2018-06-01 19:49:10.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure IPA CA generates CRL on startup

If the CRL is not generated on startup, we could have deployments
that fail because the CRL is not present when puppet goes to get
it.  This fix will ensure the CRL is generated at the start to
avoid this issue.

See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1571897

Change-Id: Ia95f78257e23f36ce35b89e0a711b713e8d1b8b4
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure IPA CA generates CRL on startup

If the CRL is not generated on startup, we could have deployments
that fail because the CRL is not present when puppet goes to get
it.  This fix will ensure the CRL is generated at the start to
avoid this issue.

See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1571897

Change-Id: Ia95f78257e23f36ce35b89e0a711b713e8d1b8b4

commit_message:
Fix Ansible warnings for use of until with {{ }}

As for 'when' clauses, 'until' should no longer use brackets, lest you
receive a written warning from Ansible.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I1f10092ce283d288ae75600c4d0a450697b37c9f

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-12 22:24:04.000000000', 'message': "Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: Ia1033404132a3d59955fca31510343b316de1458
"}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/queens

The new stable upper-constraints file is only available
after the openstack/requirements repository is branched.
This will happen around the RC1 timeframe.

Recheck and merge this change once the requirements
repository has been branched.

The CI system will work with this patch before the requirements
repository is branched because zuul configues the job to run
with a local copy of the file and defaults to the master branch.
However, accepting the patch will break the test configuration
on developers' local systems, so please wait until after the
requirements repository is branched to merge the patch.

Change-Id: Ia1033404132a3d59955fca31510343b316de1458

commit_message:
Add documentation on running os-profiler with ELK

The change documents adding os-profiler overrides into an
openstack-ansible deployment which will collect notification messages
when a profile command is executed.

To ensure the best possible outcome with os-profiler indexes a playbook
to create default indexes has been added which will create the known
index and apply appropriate settings.

Change-Id: Ie00424b2d3d123d8764cd201605ea5234a78bfbb
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Explicitly use django_nose.NoseTestSuiteRunner

Horizon is going to switch to Django Test Runner [1].
To not break Sahara Dashboard we need to use Nose Test Runner
until we'll be ready to remove Nose from sahara-dashboard.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/544296/

Change-Id: Ic248f7cc716ea0cfe8a6398438efa0a39228db85

commit_message:
Fix precreated ports recovery after pod annotations change

This patch ensure the precreated ports can be recovered upon
kuryr-controller reboot after the pod annotations format has been
changed by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/471012/

It will ensure to tag as used ports all the port ids associated to
each pod.

Closes-Bug: 1774997

so this would be nice to fix but i would like to make this more generic then things that look like ovs on x86. e.g. make it work for calico or other l3 only implementation that dont have bridges and dont assume pcie addresses as we might not have pcie buess on all plathforms or expose that info on all hypervisors. powervm i think has pcie adresss but only exposes uuids to nova i think eric can confirm?'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-02-19 14:00:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-02-19 15:02:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-02-19 16:03:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Thanks for the clarification, Sean.

Unrelated: Note that PCIe features in QEMU come _only_ with either the 
'q35' machine type for x86; or the 'virt' machine type for AArch64.

I think that should be mentioned somewhere explicitly here.

Currently Nova allows two ways to specify machine types for instances:

(1) Image metadata property:

    $ openstack image set --property \
        hw_machine_type=x86_64=pc-q35-2.10 Fedora27_Template

(2) Via a Nova config attribute:

    [libvirt]
    ...
    hw_machine_type=x86_64=pc-q35-2.10


PS: I updated the upstream QEMU pcie.txt doc to spell the machine type
    needs — 
    https://lists.nongnu.org/archive/html/qemu-devel/2018-02/msg04905.html"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-02-19 20:15:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Really don't like the idea of adding yet more CONF options for what is essentially inventory/traits information for resource providers representing "network backends" (whatever that phrase actually means...).

Yet more hardware-defined software.

I get the argument that customers are demanding "this" be fixed (even though it's not something that is "broken" in OpenStack itself). But I just fear proceeding with this spec as-written will just add a bunch of technical debt and spaghetti code to an area of the codebase (nova/virt/hardware.py and nova/pci/*) that is already virtually impossible to read and understand.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-13 16:04:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-05-23 14:18:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

To try and recap the discussion from the summit, I think we are going to:

* add the bits to the network request list objects during the thing in the api that also builds the pci request, shove that into the request spec as a vehicle to get it to the numa filter in the scheduler, but *do not* persist the network request list in the request spec (see some existing code in the request spec that filters out fields from being persisted on save)
* the limits needed for the claim in the compute will be passed from the numa filter in the scheduler through to the compute via the existing limits dict - these don't get persisted and we don't need them to be, they are per scheduling request
* we won't store the network request stuff on the instance directly, but rather via the instance.info_cache since that already contains information about the vifs and their networks and the network objects in the vif model can contain the numa information we care about, plus that gets refreshed periodically and rebuilt during some operations like live migration"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-05-23 18:08:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-05-30 14:45:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-05-30 22:29:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

This is mostly OK, just some small things that need to be updated and cleaned up I think. It's a big spec, so not surprising that some of the details were missed in the latest revision."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-05-31 12:58:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-05-31 16:42:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-06-01 09:42:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-01 12:59:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

A few questions inline, plus a new question about live migration.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-06-01 13:01:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-01 13:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-01 13:11:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review-1

We need to at least be clear about how live migration is going to be impacted by this (will it be supported and if not, why not - and what would be the plan to fix that?).

Also, should probably explicitly list a work item that during any move operation, the request spec will be modified with the existing instance info_cache so the NUMATopologyFilter properly filters hosts during the move.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-01 13:12:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

[{'created': '2018-06-04 21:46:49.000000000', 'message': 'Allow cinderv2 endpoints within the request context catalog

This partially reverts commit a03976ee892333720b2227f607a5ddbb77163fea.

This change will ensure cinderv2 endpoints are still provided by Queens
n-api control services to Pike n-cpu computes during an upgrade.
Allowing these older computes to continue to interact with Cinder prior
to upgrading to Queens and moving to the newer v3 APIs.

Closes-bug: #1775075
Change-Id: I45299df2bf095c12bfce5b1ac3e5460a11dd0131
'}, {'created': '2018-06-05 09:41:31.000000000', 'message': "Allow cinderv2 endpoints within the request context catalog

This partially reverts commit a03976ee892333720b2227f607a5ddbb77163fea.

During a P to Q upgrade it is common to have the control services
upgraded to Q ahead of the computes. During this time the Q n-api
services will provide request contexts over the wire to these P computes
where the service catalog held within does not contain any cinderv2 type
endpoints, as cinderv2 support has been removed from Nova in Q.

This becomes a problem if the P computes are specifically looking for a
cinderv2 type endpoint via [cinder]catalog_info within nova.conf.  For
example with TripleO deployed Pike environments this has a default value
of 'volumev2:cinderv2:internalURL'.

This change ensures cinderv2 type endpoints are still provided by Queens
n-api control services to Pike computes during an upgrade. This is only
required on stable/queens as we only support N-1 running computes during
an upgrade and so we don't need to land anything in R to support P
computes.

Closes-bug: #1775075
Change-Id: I45299df2bf095c12bfce5b1ac3e5460a11dd0131
"}]
commit_message:
Allow cinderv2 endpoints within the request context catalog

This partially reverts commit a03976ee892333720b2227f607a5ddbb77163fea.

During a P to Q upgrade it is common to have the control services
upgraded to Q ahead of the computes. During this time the Q n-api
services will provide request contexts over the wire to these P computes
where the service catalog held within does not contain any cinderv2 type
endpoints, as cinderv2 support has been removed from Nova in Q.

This becomes a problem if the P computes are specifically looking for a
cinderv2 type endpoint via [cinder]catalog_info within nova.conf.  For
example with TripleO deployed Pike environments this has a default value
of 'volumev2:cinderv2:internalURL'.

This change ensures cinderv2 type endpoints are still provided by Queens
n-api control services to Pike computes during an upgrade. This is only
required on stable/queens as we only support N-1 running computes during
an upgrade and so we don't need to land anything in R to support P
computes.

Closes-bug: #1775075
Change-Id: I45299df2bf095c12bfce5b1ac3e5460a11dd0131
